_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

As with any industry, there are certain inherent risks. The Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC (Facility) is taking a proactive, managed approach to risk. The Facility is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for site personnel, the community, contractors, and the environment. To meet this commitment, Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the process. One component of these systems is the Risk Management Program that has been established and implemented to assist in managing the risks involved with the storage and use of aqueous ammonia (>20 weight percent), the only hazardous substance stored and used at the Facility that is regulated pursuant to Program 2 of 40 CFR 68. 

To protect the environment, aqueous ammonia is used at the Facility to reduce oxides of nitrogen (Nox) pollutants, which are generated from the combustion of natural gas.  Specifically, ammonia is the reducing agent used in the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) pollution control systems. The SCR is a post-combustion gas treatment technique that reduces nitrous oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) in the turbine exhaust stream to molecular nitrogen and water. The SCR systems are comprised of a number of subsystems. These subsystems include the SCR reactor with associated fluework, the ammonia vaporization and injection system, and the ammonia storage and delivery system. All subsystems are equipped with the required controls and interlocks. 

The Facility is located in a sparsely populated rural area and has never had a reportable accident. Ammonia is a ubiquitous material, which is used by the surrounding farmers for fertilizer.  Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.125  Exemptions - Ammonia used as an agricultural nutrient, when held by farmers, is exempt from all provisions of this part (40 CFR 68). 

The Risk Management Plan (RMP) addresses potentially catastrophic chemical releases that could res

ult in immediate harm and acute health effects to offsite receptors (public and environmental). The RMP includes the Facility's Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that contains procedures, which are designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences. 

To foster communication with the community, the RMP and ERP have been submitted to the local fire department and the Local Emergency Response Committee (LEPC). The Facility has chosen to use a dilute solution of ammonia rather than the inherently more dangerous anhydrous form. The storage quantity of ammonia was reduced as much as possible. The storage tank area is diked and partially enclosed. The facility property is partially encompassed by a series of landscape berms, which would have a mitigating effect on an ammonia vapor plume.

At this Facility, comprehensive accidental release prevention and emergency response programs have been established. It is Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC's policy to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations. Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC is committed to the safety of workers, contractors, and the public, as well as to the preservation of the environment. Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC will implement the measures necessary to prevent foreseeable releases of the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68. The measures include:

* Employee training in accidental release prevention and emergency response programs/measures;
* Establishment of safety programs for Facility operations, design, and maintenance of the regulated process; and
* Establishment of a hazard assessment process.


Five-Year Accident History

The Facility has never had a reportable accident.


The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled

The Dynegy Kendall Energy Facility, located at 1401 County Line Road in Minooka, Illinois, is a 1,100-megawatt natural gas-fired combined-cycle power generating plant

that includes four gas turbines, four heat recovery steam generators, and four reheat condensing steam turbines. This stationary source stores and uses a regulated substance, (>20 weight percent) aqueous ammonia (CAS No. 7664-41-7), that is used in the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) pollution control systems. The RMP aqueous ammonia threshold quantity (TQ) limit is 20,000 pounds.  The maximum quantity of ammonia stored on site will not exceed 40,000 pounds (including all piping). The AST is centrally located within the Facility,  has a four (4)-foot high secondary containment dike, is protected by a roof and is enclosed on three sides, which would mitigate a potential ammonia release.

Nominal 30-weight percent aqueous ammonia is periodically delivered by tank truck (5000-6000 gallons) by trained qualified personnel using established standard operating and DOT procedures to an unloading station equipped with interconnecting piping connected to a single horizontally-orientated cylindrical 15,000-gallon above ground storage tank (AST). The 15,000-gallon AST volume is administratively controlled to 85-percent by volume (12,750-gallons) with an equivalent weight of 28,471 pounds reported as 28,000 pounds. The aqueous ammonia is stored at ambient temperature and will have a maximum pressure of 50 pounds per square inch-gauge (psig). 

Aqueous ammonia "storage" and the "vaporization / injection system" is the process considered for the RMP at this Facility. The largest quantity (vessel) of aqueous ammonia at the Facility is the 15,000-gallon AST. From the AST, the aqueous ammonia is transferred by pumps at a pressure of 120 psig and a maximum flow rate of 3 gallons per minute (gpm) to the vaporizers. The vaporized ammonia/air mixture is injected upstream of the SCR catalyst in each of the Heat Recovery Steam Generation (HRSG) units. The vaporized ammonia/air mixture is approximately at 550 degrees F.  Four new 500 gallon tanks containing ammonia diluted to <20% were

installed in April 2009.  These four tanks will receive ammonia from the anhydrous ammonia already on site.  Once the ammonia is placed in the 500 gallon tanks it will get diluted to <20% using water. 


General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps

In the event of an accidental release of the regulated substance, all efforts will be made to minimize and control the release to ensure worker safety, prevent injury to the public, or damage to the environment. Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC is committed to working with the LEPC to ensure all emergency notification and response measures are effectively planned and executed.

Both active and passive mitigation systems have been developed and implemented at the Facility to reduce the potential for adverse impacts to human health and/or the environment. The controls/measures include:
* High- and low-level aqueous ammonia AST alarm
* AST safety relief valve
* AST train analysis process (once per shift)
* AST inventory control
* AST secondary containment system
* Control room monitoring of AST operating systems
* Preventative maintenance program
* Unloading process vapor recovery system
* Manned unloading operation
* Employee training in ammonia system operations
* Concrete tank saddles to prevent ground moisture contact and subsequent corrosion

The Facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program consists of the following:
* Process Safety
* Process Hazard Analysis
* Standard Operating Procedures
* Employee Training
* Mechanical Integrity
* Work Practice Safety
* Incident Investigation/Response
* Facility Auditing

All personnel handling ammonia at the Facility are instructed to be familiar with:
* Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS)
* Evacuation Procedures
* Handling Spills and Leaks
* First Aid and Rescue Procedures
* Location and Use of Firefighting Equipment
* Proper Use of Protective Clothing
* Proper Use of Breathing Apparatus
* Location and Use of Shutoff Valves
* Location and Use of the Em

ergency STOP Button
* Location of Safety Showers and Eyewash Stations
* Operating Procedures
* Prearranged Procedures for Emergency Medical Care

Additionally, personnel involved with hazardous chemical delivery are instructed to review the following references:

Environmental, Health and Safety Manual Procedures:
* Chemical Management Work Plan
* Contractor Safety
* Emergency Response
* HAZWOPER
* Hazardous Material Delivery
* Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and Job Safety Analysis (JSA)

The Accidental Prevention Program of the RMP includes:

Process Safety:
Technical documentation, including process aqueous ammonia storage and SCR operating procedures have been developed to ensure safe operation of the regulated process as well as all plant operations. The process safety measures and documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, chemical inventories, and equipment design/configuration information and diagrams. MSDS are maintained at the Facility to provide chemical specific information. 

Process Hazard Analysis:
The Facility has a comprehensive program to help identify and control recognized hazards associated with the regulated process. Within this program, the aqueous ammonia storage and the SCR process is systematically examined to recognized hazards and to verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The process hazard analysis program is to be reviewed and updated every five (5) years, as required.

Standard Operating Procedures:
Written operating procedures for the aqueous ammonia AST system operations are in place, including system startup, normal operations, temporary operations, system shutdown and unloading operations, to ensure consistency of operations and reduce the potential for accidents. These procedures are to be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. The procedures are to be periodically reviewed for accuracy and reliability.

Training

:
To compliment the written procedures for process operations, a comprehensive employee training program has been developed for all employees involved in process operations. Training programs are designed for both new and experienced operators. New, inexperienced operators are provided basic training in plant operations. After training for new operators is complete, the new operators are to be teamed with experienced operators to learn process specific duties and tasks. After these new operators demonstrate adequate skills and knowledge of the operating requirements and safe operating practices, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all experienced operators receive annual refresher training on operating procedures.

Mechanical Integrity:
Practices and procedures have been developed to ensure process controls, pumps and compressors, pressure relief vessels, piping systems and emergency systems are operating properly. The practices/procedures include the performance of mechanical system inspections and tests to ensure proper equipment operation and the performance of preventative maintenance. Inspection and test findings are reported to designated management personnel and corrective measures are implemented, as required, to address any identified issues in a timely manner. Maintenance personnel receive training on process operations, equipment and systems maintenance procedures, emergency response, and work practice safety.

Work Practice Safety:
Work practices, including entry and exit control, equipment lockout/tagout procedures (for the isolation of energy sources when required), hazardous material management procedure, hot work program, and confined space entry programs, are followed to ensure safe working conditions.

Incident Investigation:
All incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire or explosion, toxic gas release, property damaged (major), environmental impact, or personal injury are promptly investigated to dete

rmine the cause of the incident, evaluate response measures, and prevent future recurrence.  The results of any incident investigation are provided to management personnel for review and implementation, as determined. All actions taken in response to the investigation findings/recommendation are tracked until completion.

Auditing:
The Facility will undergo a compliance audit of the accident prevention and emergency response programs to ensure adequate implementation of the programs. Audit findings and recommendations are to be provided to management personnel for review and implementation of corrective measures, as required. Any corrective measures to be implemented will be tracked by Facility personnel until completion.

Regulated toxic chemical specific prevention measures are also in place to help ensure proper use and safe management of aqueous ammonia and its associated processes. These measures will assist in preventing potential accidents caused by human error and/or equipment failures. These measures include containment system operations to help control any release of aqueous ammonia, aqueous ammonia storage system monitoring and release detection, and release mitigation measures.


Emergency Response Program

It is the policy of the Dynegy Kendall Energy, LLC to place the highest priority on employee health and safety and on protection of the environment and surrounding community from any emergency conditions that may occur at the Facility. Proper emergency response planning and communication, equipment, and employee training will assist in reducing impact arising from emergency situations. 

A written emergency response program has been established and implemented at the Facility. This program consist of procedures for responding to a hazardous substance release, including aqueous ammonia, and/or a fire or explosion. The program addresses, facility evacuation and personnel accounting, notification procedures, and post-incident cleanup and mitigation requi

rements. Also established are measures for the inspection, testing, and maintenance of emergency response equipment/systems. The program is also updated to reflect changes in operation and/or equipment.

The overall emergency response program for the Facility is coordinated with the LEPC and the local fire department. This coordination effort includes providing the fire department with site diagrams and hazardous material information, meeting with fire department personnel to discuss Facility operations/processes, and periodic on-site inspections by fire department personnel. The Facility is also equipped with 24-hour communication system for coordination with the local police and fire department. 

If a catastrophic aqueous ammonia were to occur, site personnel would dial 7-911 which dispatches the Kendall County Emergency Services Disaster Agency. 

Safety Improvement Plans

The safety improvement program includes internal safety audits.  Compliance Audits are required every 3 years (A?68.58). Hazard Reviews require updating at least once every 5 years (A?68.50). Incident Investigation Summaries shall be retained for 5 years (A?68.60).
